intro: Maytenus cassinoides, commonly known as the Mexican olive, is a small to medium-sized evergreen tree native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the family Cornaceae and is characterized by its simple, opposite, ovate leaves that are typically dark green on top and lighter underneath. The plant produces small, greenish-yellow flowers that are clustered in catkins, followed by small, fleshy berries that are an orange-red color. It is often cultivated for its ornamental value and ability to thrive in a variety of soil types, though it can be invasive in some regions.
